text: hi guys I'm Lindsay strand and today on
sweet talk I'm making peach pot pie this
is one of those desserts where simple is
best it takes the lovely flavor of ripe
summer peaches and tops it with a
beautiful flaky puff pastry crust
alright to start I have my puff pastry
rolled out here I'm just gonna take a
rolling pin
I got a nice floured surface I flower at
the top a little bit so nothing sticks
and I just want to make sure that this
is a nice smooth sheet so just give it a
little roll feels pretty good and now
for at the top I'm gonna use a 9 inch
cake pan to trace a circle you could
also use your pie plate but you would
have to trim it a little bit after
cutting so I'll use a 9-inch cake pan
and I'm just gonna use a paring knife to
cut around the edge of the cake pan my
dough is a little bit soft if it's
getting hard to work with you can always
pop it back into the refrigerator to
firm up again using a kind of like a
light sawing motion to cut a circle here
you could also use a pastry trimmer or a
little pizza cutter those both work
really well for this kind of application
now I'll lift away the excess you can
always keep this and you can cut little
twists make puff pastry twist make
cheese straws you definitely don't have
to get rid of this so for now I'm just
gonna set this aside and then now that I
have my round I'm gonna score lines two
inches apart in a crosshatch pattern so
let's see it's gonna score little
notches every two inches
[Music]
lightly put that you don't want to go
all the way through it's okay if you
slip up in a couple places it's not
gonna do any harm but I like to do this
on a piece of floured parchment so that
if you do accidentally cut through you
can slide it all over to the baking
sheet at the same time and one more down
here now I'll go the other way
this crosshatch makes a really nice
quilted pattern when it puffs up makes
these little beautiful pillows of crisp
flaky sugary dough I think it needs one
more line over here just like that and
now I'm gonna transfer this onto a
baking sheet normally I like to use
rimmed baking sheets this is one
application where it's really nice to
just slide it right onto a cookie sheet
and this is going to chill in the
freezer while I make my peach filling so
for my filling I have one with 3/4 pound
of peaches which is about five nice ripe
summer peaches you could use frozen for
this if you want to just make sure you
saw them out all the way before you use
them I'm just cutting around the pit on
this because I find that sometimes these
are cling stones and then it's really
tough to get them off cleanly and then
I'm just slicing these into half-inch
slices I like keeping the skin on
because they have that lovely blush
color that kind of adds a nice pinky
peachy hue to your pie but you could
definitely peel them if you wanted to
just add these in here and then to the
peaches I'm adding a quarter cup of
brown sugar just adds a nice caramel
eNOS two tablespoons of cornstarch this
is our thickener this will thicken the
juices from the peaches not too much
because you don't want it to be like
jelly but just enough so that the
peaches are set half a teaspoon of
kosher salt because as always salty with
our sweets a tablespoon of bourbon this
is optional you don't have to use it but
it adds a really
nice depth of flavor to this dish I
think it works so well with the peaches
with the brown sugar and you can't
really taste the alcohol that just adds
a little hint of warmth and finally a
teaspoon of vanilla extract so this is
basically like making a pie filling you
have your sweetness you have a little
bit of a flavor hint from the Bourbon
you have your thickener you know a
little bit of salt so it's just like
making a pie filling except we're not
lining the bottom of our pie dish so
something I love about this recipe is
it's almost like making half of a pie
it's a little less work all right so
that's combined and I'm pouring this
into my 9-inch pie plate mmm
the bourbon and the peaches already
smells incredible we spread these into
an even layer they look so beautiful I
love those pretty red skins on the
peaches and since this needs a little

tightly around the edges so that
Cape we want to put all of those juices
inside this is going into a 350 degree
oven for 20 minutes my fruits been in
the oven for about 20 minutes it's
getting nice and bubbly and while that
happens I'm gonna make an egg wash for
my puff pastry crust so here I have a
large egg and I'm adding a little bit of
water I find that this helps it thin out
a little bit so you don't get big clumps
of egg in your egg wash like whisk here
definitely use a fork for this too if
you don't have one of these little mini

even use it to foam milk for a lot types
of ends alright that looks pretty good
and shouldn't like they brush this over
my puff pastry you don't want to do too
much because then you'll lose your
definition on some of those nice clothes
and lines you put in but just enough so
that it gets a nice shiny deeply golden
crust that looks good you don't have to
throw that away you can always throw
that into your morning omelet use it for
something else this is basically 1 eggs
worth right here and then I have a
little bit of coarse sanding sugar here
you could definitely use regular
granulated sugar or maybe even a colored
sanding sugar if that's what you have
but I think this is a really pretty way
to top the crust on the pie you can skip
this entirely if you want but this does
add a really nice crunch to the puff
pastry so just a light sprinkle there
and now this is going into the same oven
with the fruit for about 40 to 50
minutes until this is deeply golden all
over puffed completely cooked through
and the fruit should be bubbling
all right so I just pulled both of these

a chance to melt together and be really
